div.head: To the Honorable Sr WALTER LONG, BARONET.
div.p:
I Hope not to incur your blame, when I prefix your Name to this mall Treatie. The Matter is new, though long ought after; the cope is the
publick good, and my private aim is to hew my gratitude for o many obligations you have been pleaed to lay upon me, beides my hopes, that the deign of the Subject may perhaps be approved by experiment, and the malnes of the Volume pas among thoe things that are not illuory. And to ay truth, under whoe Wings could I have heltered it better than yours? Whoe Affability and Candor is open to the
greatet Strangers, and particularly my Self, with your never enough to be commended, generous Hopitality.

But my intention here, being not to make your Panegyrick, I uperede and pare your Modety, it being ufficient to me, if the Author and the Work can deerve your Protection, and the favorable Looks of your worthy Brother, Mater Robert
Long, and o ingage me to remain the ret of my days

closer.signed: Your mot humble and affectionate Servant Garencieres.

div.head: CHAP. I.
Of Coral, and of the divers kinds thereof.
div.p: COral is a Shrub, growing in the bottom of the Sea, which becometh Stony when expoed to the Air.

q.l: Sic & Coralium, quo primum contigit auras
Tempore, durecit; mollis fuit herba ub undis.

div.p:
Therefore is it called by the Greeks
< in non-Latin alphabet >
and < in non-Latin alphabet > , that is, The Stony Tree, in Latin Coralium.

There is divers orts of it according to their everal colours; for there is a Red, a White, a Black, a Green, a Yellowih, of an Ah-colour and of mixed colours. The Red,
which is called the Male, is preferred above all the ret, and is the ubject of this our Treatie. Anelmus de Booth, Phyician to the Emperor Rodolphus the Second, affirmeth, To have een in the aid Emperors Cabinet, Branches of Coral of everal colours upon the ame Body; o that the Body of it was Coral and Stony, and the Branches Ligneous and Woody, which is not improbable to me; for I have een in the North of Ireland a Lake called Lake Neaugh, wherein, if a piece of Wood that groweth thereabout be planted, that part which is in the Ground hall be turned into Iron, that which is in the Water into Stone, and what is above Water hall remain Wood. But let us come to Coral again, whoe generation is not much unlike; for when that Juyce that is in it, called by the Latins, Succus Lapidecens, runneth thorough the Body of the Vegetable, it altereth it, and turneth it into a tony ubtance. Whence we may g • es, That Coral, under Water, is not altogether oft and flexible, though it groweth tony, when expoed to the Air; which cannot be wondered at, eeing there be many Stones, both in France and England, which being newly digged out of the Ground, are in a manner as oft as Cheee: But having been a while expoed
to the Air, grow to a coniderable hardnes, the Sun and the Air having exhauted the waterih part of them. Now whether Coral groweth out of the Petrifying Juyce, or being ingendred as other Plants, is at lat altered by the aid Petrifying Juyce, is a quetion. For my part, I believe that it doth not grow without that Petrifying Juyce, no more then the Sea-fan, called Corallina, the Alga, and other Herbs which grow in the Sea, and that it doth not petrifie till it dieth: By dying, I mean, that when by the ordinary coure of Nature, or by the violent action of the Stony Juyce, penetrating the inmot parts, the Plant is petrified. Now it is certain, that Nature maketh ue ometimes of the Petrifying Juyce for the producing of the Plant; for it hath been oberved by many, that Coral hath grown out of the pieces and fragments of Earthen Pots. And in the Iland called Tabacco, near Africa, which is half wallowed up by the Sea, much Coral is found, having its Roots in pieces of Earthen Pots. Now the reaon why Coral hould petrifie, and other Plants not, is becaue of its peculiar dipoition: As alo, becaue naturally there is a Petrifying Juyce in it, which forceth the Plant to receive a tony form; beides the peculiar dipoition,
and preparation of it to receive uch a form. No reaon can be given for its colour, no more then for that of a Roe; for it cannot be referred to the firt or econd qualities, no more than the ight of the eye. God hath been pleaed to adorn things with uch colours, and hath o inerted them into their Seeds, as their Archaeus can produce none other; Coral ometimes groweth to the height of a man before it be ripe and turned Red, it eemeth of everal colours; for as many Plants as I have een that were not wholly petrified, were all of a Dusky, Green, or uch colour as we ee in other Trees; and thoe only begun to be Red, that had nothing woody in them, as we ee that in Pears and Apples, the Red colour is a ign of their ripenes and maturity. When Coral is newly taken out of the Sea, many impure things tick to it outwardly, which being taken of, the true colour heweth it elf. There are everal orts of Coral in repect of their matter, for ome is oft, other hard, ome olid, ome hollow, ome rough, ome polihed, ome porous.

When Coral is taken out of the Sea, it is for the mot part rough, and then is made mooth and polihed by the Artits: There is a Black Coral found in Gallicia, a Province
of Spain, and uch another ort of coure one, called Savalia, is brought from Mauritany, having the inide woody, and the outide horny, and tony, of a Black, Yellow, and Green colour. There is alo a ort of White Coral found in Catalonia, and called by the Spaniards Polo: This hath no Bark, and groweth in the bottom of the Sea, and not upon Rocks, as the Red doth. The bet Coral is now found upon the Coats of Tunis and Tripoli. Theophratus in his Book
< in non-Latin alphabet > reckoneth Coral among the precious Stones; and Orpheus in his Book < in non-Latin alphabet >
peaketh very much of Coral. Before I end this Chapter, and peak of the Virtues of Coral, I will here, in favor of the curious, clear a doubt, and hew an error concerning its Nature that hath reigned a great while (becaue Pliny writeth, that Coral while it is in the Sea, is as oft as Wax, but aoon as it cometh to the Air it groweth hard) by an Hitory, taken out of. Beguinus own words in his Tyrocinium Chymicum.

Upon this Controverie, Iohn Baptit of Nicole, Squire of the City of Mareilles, chief Commander for the Fihing of Coral in the Kingdom of Tunis, hath aured me, That in the year One thouand five hundred eighty four, being upon the Sea of Bierty, belonging
to the aid Tunis, where the aid Fihing of Coral was, and being curious to know the Nature of Coral, and how it groweth in the bottom of the Sea, caued a young Man to dive into the Sea a hundred fathom deep, being tied to a rope of a ufficient length, with a weight of five and twenty pounds in each hand, to go to the bottom, charging him to bring ome Coral from the bottom, and to oberve, whether it was hard or oft. Being come above Water, he brought a Branch of Coral in each hand, affirming, That it was as hard in the bottom of the Sea, as out of it, and that being about eight or nine fathoms near the bottom, he felt an exceive cold. The ame Nicole not contented therewith, as the Nets were coming up, and before they could be in the Air, cat himelf into the Sea about one fathom deep, and took ome Coral ticking to the Nets, which he found as hard as when it is in the Air. The ame hath been confirmed to be me by the Lord of La Piotier, a Gentleman of Lion, who within thee two years returned from the aid Fihing of Coral. Beides this, the aid Squire Nicole aured me, that in the Spring when the Coral is plucked up, in the breaking of it, there iueth out a liquor like unto Milk, which falling upon any Stone,
Wood, Iron, or ome other matter, produceth Coral; and that he had een in the Cabinet of the great Duke at Pia, the Skull of a dead Man, upon which was grown in the Sea, a great Branch of Coral; and an Anchor taken out of the Sea, upon which were everal Branches of Coral, produced by the Juyce of Coral that fell upon it.

Here we mut rectifie a kind of eeming contradiction, which is, when we have cited Ovid and Mathiolus, and aid, That Coral was oft under Water, and grew hard when it came into the Air; and in another place, That by the experiment of Squire Nicole, it was found to be hard under Water; therefore undertand this only to be Secundum magis & minus, as of thoe Stones which we have aid to be as oft as Cheee in the Earth, and then to harden in the Air when digged up, for the Reaons before alledged. For though Coral may be hard in the bottom of the Sea, yet it is nothing o hard as when it hath been expoed a while to the Air; and o we perceive it to be in all kind of Trees which dry and harden to the Air, when once weaned and eparated from their natural ap or moiture, and growing place.

div.head: CHAP. II.
Of the Nature, Faculties, and virtues of Coral.
div.p:
ACcording to the Famous Diocorides and his Learned Commentator Mathiolus, Coral in his manifet qualities is moderately atringent and cooling; but his pecifick qualities, are o many and wonderful, that I hould how my elf too prolix and tedious, if I would treat of them one by one. Therefore I hall content my elf to lay down the chiefet, and to back them with the Authority of everal Learned and Famous Men, and hall begin with Anelmus de Booth, Phyician to the Emperor Rodolphus the Second, in his Book De Gemmis & Lapidibus, wherein he aith, That the tincture of Coral toppeth the immoderate Coures of Women, both Red and White; the Running of the Reins; the Spitting of Blood; and cureth all Bloody Fluxes, and Gripings of the Guts; expelleth all kind of Gravel and Stones, and conumeth the over-growing of the Spleen. I can tetifie of my elf (aith he) that being extreamly ick of a Petilential Feaver, and fainting
every moment, and having been without leep four days and four nights; inomuch, that all thoe about me, depaired of my life, by taking in a Spoon ix drops of the aid Tincture, with the decoction of Violets, upon an intant, and as it were miraculouly, I was cured. For aoon as I had taken two Spoonfuls of the aid Tincture, I felt my Vital Spirits o refrehed, and my Intrals o comforted by the gratefulnes and efficacy of the aid Remedy; that as if the Light had expelled Darknes, I found manifetly the trength of the dieae abated, and fell into a critical Sweat (of which before there was no ign.) So that Nature did thrut to the skin abundance of Purple Spots, which preently being obliterated and carried away by the Sweat, in a little time I recovered my former health. That Tincture (aith he) hath the faculty to bring the Body to a right temper by a certain Celetial Power, and eradicateth all Dieaes out of the Internal Parts, by reaon of the Analogy it hath with the Vital Spirits, and the natural heat which it augmenteth and trenghtneth, and therefore overcometh eaily the contrary Dieaes. It cureth the Falling Sicknes in few weeks, though one hath had it from his youth. It is commended above all againt the immoderate Fluxes of Women, either White or Red; for it doth tay them o, that
<1 page duplicate>
<1 page duplicate>
the Women cannot fall into any inconveniency by it. It doth alo top all Fluxes of the Belly, and of the Blood from whatoever part it floweth. It alo toppeth the old Runnings of the Reins. It is given in the Plague with admirable ucces: Likewie in the Flux and Small Pox, chiefly when they do not come out kindly. It is alo excellent againt Melancholy and the Tympany. It appeaeth the Pains of the Eyes, tayeth the Rheum, and taketh away the Spots that grow in the Eyes.

In a word, Coral trengthneth the Heart, and therefore is a overaign Remedy againt the Plague, and all venemous, contagious, and malignant Dieaes. It is a certain Antidote in the Plague time, if one taketh of the aid Tincture in a Morning fating, the quantity of half a drachm. It hath the ame power againt the poion of Vitriol, which is analogal to that of Feavers and Agues, cauing Gripings in the Stomach, and the Guts, Vomiting, Looenes, thicknes and blacknes of the Tongue, Short-breath, and other dangerous Symptoms, which is confirmed by Foretus, Lib. 30. Obervat. Med. Obervatione 7. in Scholio. Arnaldus Villanovanus relateth, That if ten grains of the Tincture of Coral be given to a Child newly born,
mixed with ome of the Mothers Milk, before the Child hath taken any other Meat or Drink, that the aid Child hall never be troubled with the Falling-Sicknes; which is alo affirmed by Camillus Leonardus, Lib. 2. Speculi Lapidum, Litera, c. Thus far Anelmus de Booth.

Our econd Author hall be Crollius, the Prince of Chymits, who aith this. As Coral doth wonderfully grow, o the Secrets that are in it, are altogether admirable, and its Faculties beyond expreion. The virtue of its Tincture is uch, that it is able to cleane and renew the Blood in uch ort, as to cure all Dieaes that comes from the corruption thereof, and to retore health, trength, and alacrity. It toppeth all immoderate Fluxes in Women, being taken in Plantain Water; as alo all Lasks and Fluxes of the Belly, as Bloody Fluxes, Dyenteries, Diarrhoea's, taken in the decoction of the Roots of Tormentil; all Haemorrhagies, Spitting of Blood, and Haemorrhoides, taken in Plantain Water; cleaneth and reneweth the Blood, taken in the Water of Fumitory or Cichory. Reiteth Putrefaction, trengthneth the Heart, and the Vital Spirits, and preerveth them from Poion, in Water of Borrage or Bugloe. Comforeth and trengthneth the Stomach, and
the Natural heat in Mint or Penniroyal Water. Removeth all obtructions, chiefly from the Lungs, Liver, and Kidneys, in Water of Sorrel, Gras, Little Centaury, Spleenwort, Liverwort. Diolveth congealed Blood in Water of Chervil or Daiie. It cureth abolutely the Fits of the Mother, and the immoderate Fluxes of Women, in the Water of Motherwort, Balm, Penniroyal. It cureth the Dropie, Convulion, Palie, Falling-Sicknes, in Cinnamon Water, continuing for a while. It expelleth the Stone and Gravel in Saxifrage Water, or that of Ret-Harrow. The doe is from ix grains or ten, to a cruple or two, according to the age of the Patient, and the greatnes of the ditemper. It cureth Ulcers being applied to them, or mixed with Plaiters proper for them.

The third Author hall be Joannes Petrus Faber, a famous Phyician of Monpelier, who in his Book called Myrothecium Spagiricum, in the Chapter of Coral, peaketh thus. The virtues and force of this Secret for the mund •• ying, and purifying the Blood in all the Body, is uch as it may be given in all ick
••••••
and dieaes, which proceed from the
<> of the Blood, in o much that it
<> excellent in the Leproie. It tayeth
<> Fluxes in Women being taken
in Plantain Water; as alo all kinds of Looenees, and other Bloody Fluxes againt Nature. It comforteth and trengthneth the Heart wonderfully, as alo the Stomach. Retoreth the Natural heat, by reaon of its radical moiture, which is almot equal to ours. It diolveth all Congealed Blood and Scorbutical Concretions, therefore alo mot profitable to thoe that have the Stone and Gravel, being drunk in the Water of Ret-Harrow. It is wonderfully efficacious in all venemous Ulcers, and others, if it be mixed with ome proper Balam, becaue it mundifieth the Blood, and procureth Cicatrization.

The fourth Author hall be our worthy Countreyman, Roger Bacon, who in his Learned Treatie De Retardanda Senectute, commendeth Coral in thee words. That Remedy which lieth in the bottom of the Sea, is of a wonderful virtue againt the infirmities of old age, as experience teacheth us. It is hot and dry in the econd degree, as Iaac affirmeth. It doth corroborate the Stomach, the Senes, and all the internal parts.

The fifth Author hall be the mot renowned Fernelius, who peaking of Coral, aith thus; Coral being cold and dry in the econd degree, by his Atringent quality trengthneth the Stomach, and efficaciouly toppeth all Bloody
Fluxes, preerveth the trength of the Heart, and fenceth it againt all malignant and petilent Dieaes. Being taken inwardly, it tayeth the monethly Coures of Women, and trengthneth the Conception. It hindereth Excrecences of Fleh, filleth up the cavity of Ulcers, and weareth out the Scars in the Eyes. It cooleth the heat of Choler, and tayeth the eruptions of it, whether upward or downward. It trengthneth the ubtance of the Liver, let it never be o looe.

I could in confirmation of the Premies, bring the authority of all the bet Phyicians in all Ages that have made mention of Coral, but that I am an Enemy to Prolixity and Repetitions. Thee will erve to atisfie any reaonable peron, or ele nothing will.

In a word, the Virtues of Coral are o great and wonderful, that many grave and authentical Authors did not tick to ay, That it was an Amulet or Charm againt Fearfulnes, Bewitchings, Sorceries, Poyons, Falling-Sicknes, Aaults of the Devil, Lightnings, Seatorms, and other dangers whatoever. Therefore in ancient time it was dedicated to Jupiter and Apollo. But of thee lat qualities, let every one believe as much as he thinketh fitting: Certain it is, by the tetimony of Pliny, and others, that anciently it was among the
Indians almot of an equal value with Pearls of the ame bignes. It is alo certain, that Red Coral, if worn by a Man, hath, and preerveth its colour better than that which is worn by a Woman; perhaps, becaue the heat of a Man is greater than that of a Woman; and the vapors that exhale out of his Body are purer.

Moreover, it is an undoubted truth, That Red Coral will grow pale, blewih, and maculated with everal pots when it is worn by one that is nigh death, or dangerouly ick, and will foretel Dieaes by the changing of its colour. This I found true by a ad experience of my own; for having once a Girl about Twelve Moneths old that wore a Bracelet of Coral, he fell into a Petilential Feaver: So that when I came home and pied the Coral quite altered, I began preently to depair of her recovery, which I would not have done, if I had known then the Tincture of Coral, as I do now. She lived but two days in that cae. After her death I would have taken the Bracelet from her, and tried whether I could have brought it to its former colour again; but the Mother would never uffer it, but would have it buried with her, let the ight of it hould bring her into remembrance of her los, and o deprived me
