of o jut a curioity. Here by the By, Let us conider what affliction it is to Parents to ee their young Children ick, without any Remedy, and not able to expres their own grievances, whereas now a poonful of this Tincture, which is pleaant to the tate, and can be no ways hurtful, may preerve them alive to the honor and glory of God, and the atisfaction, and joy of their Parents and Relations.

div.head: CHAP. III.
Of the Tincture of Coral; and what is Tincture.
div.p:
TIncture is an Extract of the Colours adhering to mixed Bodies, and of the formal qualities thereof. Whence cometh it, that Tinctures are ometimes called Oyls, ometimes Spirits, and ometimes Quintecence. In the Extraction of Tinctures, the Chymical Artits do chiefly labor, that they may eparate the formal Virtue of the mixed Bodies, in which lieth the faculty of curing Dieaes from its proper Matter or Feculent Body, which is unprofitable, Terretrial or Waterih; for they draw by Extraction and Means of a determinated Mentruum (for the ame Mentruum is not fit to draw all kinds of Tinctures) the Tincture or Eence of it, which is the mot ecret and internal ubtance that Nature had incloed and concealed in the Intrals of it, to preerve it from all external injuries and accidents. And after that, they draw or abtract the Mentruum from it; and the Tincture or Eence remaineth in the bottom of the Veel, in the conitence of Honey
or Pap, and then it is properly called Extract. But if it be in a Liquid form joyned with its Mentruum, and repreenting the colour out of which it is drawn, then it is properly called Tincture. Therefore oberve that by the word Tincture, the Chymits undertand the colours ticking to the Eence of the mixed Bodies, and to the formal qualities drawn out of them.

Here we mut make an exact ditinction, between a Diolution and an Extraction of the Tincture; for in a true Tincture we extract only the formal Virtue of the ubject, the mas and lump of the Body remaining whole; but in a diolution, the whole compound is reduced into minute parts. Hence cometh it, that the doe of the Tincture is mall, but that of the diolution mut be in a greater quantity, becaue it is not o efficacious.

Oberve alo, That there is no true Tincture, but that which remaineth of the ame colour as the mixed Body was, after the Mentruum is extracted from it. If by this rule many Tinctures be examined, it will be eaily known that they are no true Tinctures, but that their colour proceedeth from the mixture of the Mentruum with the Body diolved.

For example, Let any body take of the Vulgar Tinctures of Coral, if you exhale or ditil the Mentruum from them, it will go away pure and clear, and that which remaineth hall not be Red, but hall look either like Lime or Salt; whereas, if it were a true Tincture, and a Red Subtance extracted from the Body, it hould remain o, though the Mentruum were abtracted from it. But that Tinctures are not always true, but vary according to their Mentruums, is evident in that everal colours may be extracted out of one and the ame thing by everal Mentruums. For example, if you put upon Silver calcined with Mercury ublimate, the Spirit of Salt; you hall have a Green colour like an Emerald, but if you put upon it the Spirit of rine impregnated with the Salt of rine, it will be of a Blew colour. Thee contradictions did perwade once Crollius, an excellent Chymit, when he wrote his Book called Bailica Chymica, That the true Tincture of Coral was impoible to be had, or at leat, that it was not his fortune ever to ee any. But we hall convince him ufficiently of the contrary, and as many as hall be of his opinion.

Here I cannot wonder enough at many Chymits and Phyicians of good note, who through ignorance, or by hear-ay, for the
obtaining the Tincture of Coral, advie to calcine it, that the Tincture may be drawn out of it, without conidering that in the Calcination the fire burneth and conumeth the Tincture, and that Calcination is good for nothing but to Extract the Salt of it, which alo hath everal Faculties in Phyick of which we hall peak in its proper place. For Calcination is the Reduction of a mixed Body into a Calx or Lime made by fire, which depriveth the aid mixed Body of the humor or moiture that united the parts together.

Now it is time to come to the true Tincture of Coral. Take therefore (for an experiment) half an ounce of the bet Coral in Powder, put it in a Viol of about half a pint, pour upon it ix ounces of our Mentruum, and top the Viol cloe with a Cork, you hall perceive, that within four hours the aid Mentruum will be coloured Red, then pour it out, and put new upon the ame Coral, and o do, o often till you hall ee the Coral white in the bottom of the Glas, then abtract the Mentruum in Balneo, in the bottom hall remain the true Tincture of Coral as Red as Blood, and the Body hall remain in the Viol as white as Snow: Edulcorate, that is, Wah the aid Tincture from its Mentruum with ome Cordial
Water, which you hall afterwards Abtract from the Tincture in Balneo, till it be almot dry, then halt thou have the true Tincture of Coral, mot efficacious for the aforementioned Dieaes, being given in ome appropriated Vehiculum, and fit for the ditemper. The doe is from ten drops to twenty, or thirty, in two ounces of an appropriated Liquor.

When you have Extracted the Tincture of Coral, do not light or throw away the Body of Coral which remaineth in the Viol, for out of it may, by Chymical Art, be Extracted the Salt of Coral; which in all repects emulateth and cometh very near the Tincture, except in the curing of malignant and petilential Dieaes.

I am here much urpried at the contradictory opinion of Philibert Guibert, a famous Phyician of Paris, who in everal places of his Book, called The Charitable Phyician, having highly commended the ue of Venice Treacle againt the Plague, and other ven •
mous Dieaes, according to the doctrine of the bet Phyicians, doth at lat in his Treatie of the Plague, exclaim againt it as againt an infamous Remedy, contrary to the authority of the bet Phyicians, and the contant experience of all Ages, as I have hewed in
my Treatie of the lat Plague Anno 1665. and intead of it, ubtituteth two Antidotes of his own, which are omething Comical. The firt is, The ue of good Wine; the econd is that which he calleth Electuarium de tribus Adverbiis. Cito, longe, tarde. That is, to be gone quickly out of the infected place, to go far from it, and to come back as late as one can, according to this old Ditich.

q.l: Haec tria tabificam pellunt Adverbia Petem,
Mox, longe, tarde, cede, recede, redi.

div.p: But as we do not deny that Wine is a noble Aliment, and a great Cordial, o do we think it too weak alone to cure the Plague, as is een in many places where people drink nothing but Wine, and that of the bet: No more than his Antidote of the three Adverbs, many having met with the Plague in the Countrey, which they might have avoided, if they had tayed in the City, as I did all the while: For I do undertake (with the Grace of God) to cure the fiercet Plague with Venice Treacle, and my Tincture of Coral. Add to this, that many people are not able to go out of Town, either want of means or relations, or being incumbred with a numerous Fam • ly.

Before we finih this Chapter, it will be worth the curioity of the Reader to know how to Extract the Salt of Coral, which we have aid to emulate the Virtues of the Tincture, except in the curing of the Plague, and malignant Feavers.

Take therefore that white Body of Coral which remaineth in the Viol, after the Extraction of the Tincture, wah it very well with fair water, dry it gently upon a oft fire, and then pour upon it by degrees Vinegar, that hath been ditilled three times, as much as will cover it four Fingers above, then diget and diolve that together, and after the olution, Abtract the Vinegar till the Coral be dry; then wah the Coral with ditilled water, to take away the acrimony of the Vinegar; after that, evaporate the Water till there remaineth a Salt as white as Snow, and free from all acrimony, which mut be kept in a Glas cloe topt.

Its virtues are mot excellent, for it purifieth the Blood in all the Body, which it retoreth to its former trength. It toppeth all Fluxes of the Womb, of the Belly, and of the Haemorrhoides. It trengthneth the Heart, and the Stomach; it openeth all the obtructions of the internal parts; it diolveth congealed Blood. It is mot excellent in the
Dropie, Palie, Convulion, the Stone, Fits of the Mother. Crollius is of the ame opinion; for he aith, That it purifieth the Blood, and cureth in a hort time all Dieaes that proceed from the corruption of it, if it be taken in Cichory or Fumitory Water. To top all exceive Fluxes and los of Blood, as well by Dyenteries and Haemorrhoides, and uch like; as Hepatical Fluxes, Lienterical, Mentrual, Spermatical, Bleeding at the Noe, Spitting of Blood, being taken in Plantain Water, or uch like; to reit putrefaction, to trengthen the Brains, the Stomach, the Natural heat, and the Vital Spirits, and to preerve the Heart againt all poyon; to remove all obtructions from the noble parts, to wit, The Lungs, the Liver, and the Kidneys; to diolve congealed Blood, and to cure the mot tubborn Fits of the Mother, and uperfluities of the Monethly Coures, being taken in the Water of Motherwort, Balm, or Pennyroyal. See Crollius in Bailica Chymica, and Anelmus de Booth, cap. 154. Lib. 3. de Gemmis.

In the Dropie, Palie, Falling-Sicknes, and Convulion, this Salt is taken with admirable ucces in Cinnamon Water; and for the Stone, in the Water of Ret-Harrow. It
may alo be put in Lozenges, and be taken in tead of common Salt in a boiled Egg, or in Broth, or in White Wine.

div.head: CHAP. IV.
Why in the Curing of Dieaes, we chue rather to make ue of the Tincture of Coral, then of the whole Body in Substance however prepared.
div.p: DIeaes never come upon mankind, but by a Segregation and Heterogeneity of humors; for while the Crais or Temperament of the Humors, remaineth whole, Nature contantly performeth her Functions, the Spirits play their part, and the oeconomy of the Body remaineth intire; but aoon as the Humors begin to eparate themelves, and to jar one againt another, the Spirits are cattered, the Humors putrifie; and if there be any malignity in the Air, it introduceth itelf immediately into that Chaos.

Now thee Indications teach Phyicians, firt, to expel the malignity as the mot presing; econdly, to ettle the Spirits; thirdly, to unite again the Humors. Now the malignity being aerial, cannot be expelled, but by formal Qualities, neither can the Spirits be ettled but by the ame; which both being done, the third, which is the union of the
Humors, will of neceity follow; for the Caue being removed, the Effect inueth. Thee things cannot eaily be done by a Body in Subtance, (uppoe Coral in Powder) for in that Body the three Principles of Nature, to wit, Salt, Sulphur, and Mercury, remain united together, and o adhere one to another; that although nature may diget them, yet will they not eparate themelves to do the Body any determinate good, but will either undigeted or digeted, go all along and keep company together; whereas, when they are eparated one from the other, they work determinately by the help of a proper Vehiculum, upon the dieae aimed at. For though all the parts (for example of Coral) be friendly to an Humane Body, yet are they more friendly one to another, and will not eparate themelves to do a Body good, but will rather tick cloe and perih together, to the illuion of the Phyician, and the deluion of the Patient. The econd Reaon is, That when the Remedy is given in Subtance, Nature is put to the work and task of digeting it, and in the mean time the dieae (chiefly if it be aerial) getteth footing, the trength declineth, and o many times the Scales weigh down; whereas, if it be given eparate (uppoe the Tincture of Coral) Nature preently layeth
hold on it, cheareth up the heart with it, who preently as the Sun of the Microcom endeth it, by way of irradiation, to the part affected, and o relieveth the Patient.

Another inconveniency arieth from giving Remedies in Subtance, which is, that when the thinnet part of the Remedy, is diolved in the Body, the thicket, which the Latins call Faere or Craamentum, remains in the way, and many times caueth tubborn obtructions, and other accidents, whoe Caues being unknown to the Phyician, becaue unupected, produce many times everal accidents wore than the Dieae that was intended at firt to be cured. This is to be daily oberved in thoe that ue gros and f;aeculent Means, and by the Reaon we have alledged before, fall into toppages and obtructions, and conequently into divers Dieaes hard to be cured.

From this Reaon it is, that Spirits and Eences eparated and ublimated, work more powerfully and efficaciouly, than when they are wrapt and involved in their whole Bodies, <> whom they cannot eaily extricate themelves, and hew forth their power and virtue, as you may oberve in Spirit of Wine well rectified, one poonful of which hall work more effect then a quart
of the common one, out of which it is extracted. The ame is of Vinegar, which, if it be pure and good, hall in the quantity of a poonful, in Sawces, Salets, or other condiments, do more effect than a quart of the common one, and with les charge and more gratefulnes; becaue its efficacy and virtue before was dulled, allayed, and made inefficacious by the faeces, phlegm, and other impurities that adhered to it. Upon this Reaon, the Remedies that are to be adminitred to Humane Bodies, are to be pure, rectified and exalted: If you well conider the effect you expect from them, and the dignity of the ubject with whom you have to do. Therefore the bet Chymits in all Ages have endeavored and labored to make their Remedies as pure and defaecated as poibly they could, that the effect aimed at, might follow, and the Humane Bodies excellency hould not be violated, as it is not, when in the preparation of the Remedies, the pure is eparated from the impure, the ueful from the unprofitable, the piritual from the corporeal, and the cordial from the poyon: And thus they do not lie heavy upon the Stomach, they beget no impurities, caue no new obtructions, but immediately fight againt the Dieaes, and overcome them. Thus, Beer well ettled
is wholeomer than new; thus Wine eparated from its Tartar, is better for the tate, and for the health, then when it is newly extracted from the Grape; thus the Meats we eat, being eparated by Nature from their Excrements, after many light concoctions and eparations of Excrements in the Liver, and in the Veins, are at lat made fitter for the nourihment of the parts. Thus, Cinnamon Water hall ooner and more efficaciouly comfort the Heart, than Cinnamon it elf in Subtance; thus, a few drops of Oyl of Annieed hall work more effectually then many Seeds, and thus of the ret. Whereby you may ee that Remedies well prepared and purified, are extraordinary efficacious for the cure of the wore Dieaes; as the Fallingicknes, the Convulion, the Dropie, the
• uartan Ague, the Gout, and other Dieaes commonly deemed incurable; and that with all afety diligence, and alacrity, imitating Nature in this, which doth not end to the parts for their nourihment the Meats as they are raw and whole, but altereth them in the Stomach, digeteth and detroyeth them, and in the Liver eparateth the puret from the Excrements.

Now concerning the penetration of the Virtue of the Tincture of Coral, to the remotet
parts, for the Curing of thoe deperate Dieaes, we have mentioned, as Fallingicknes, Convulion, Gout, Pox, Bleeding out of any part of the Body, &c. Conider how the Milk of a Nure that hath taken Rheubarb, is able to purge a Suckling-Infant, &c.

div.head: How the Tincture of Coral worketh upon Dieaes.
div.p:
BUt that we may make this obvious to the meanet capacities, we will lay here open the mot ecret Foundations of Phyick, to wit, The Actinobolim of Natural things, which is no where ele o clearly to be een as in Medicinal ones; and this is twofold, either to life or to death. Which that you may undertand, you mut oberve, That as all things were created for Mans ake, even o there was given to every one a particular virtue by which Man might be preerved: For he that intendeth the End, intendeth alo the Means to attain it, as are the Virtues of Natural things. Seeing then that there is no Member in an Humane Body, but hath its proper and peculiar infirmities, the mot High hath provided Remedies againt all them; eeing alo that there be Members hidden and concealed in the mot retired places of the Body, where there was no acces for Herbs and Plants to come to. He hath given them like as it were Beams of Light, preding themelves round like thoe of the Sun, which paing through all the Body, do by their Actinobolim or
Irradiation, penetrate to that Member which is correpondent to them, and hath need of their Faculties and Virtues. Hence cometh, that the Remedies having pred the Beams of their Virtues, go directly to that Member which is analogal and correpondent with them, and trengthen and comfort it. Thus all Cordials by their Actinobolim, do not meddle with the Liver, Brains, or Spleen; but with the Heart.

The Hepatical Remedies by their Actinobolim, do not comfort the Kidneys or the Lungs, but the Liver: Thus, the Diureticks meddle not with the Liver, Heart, or Brains, but with the emulgent Veins, and the Bladder. Thus, the Actinobolim of the Catharticks and Diaphoreticks, gather together into the Intrals, all the Choler lurking in the Body, and from thence carry it away as a uperfluous and noxious thing.

Hence it is manifet, by what Reaon the compounded Medicines, indowed with divers qualities, work upon the Body unconfuedly, and are no hinderance one to another, no more than the Suns Beams are among themelves, as it is demontrable in Mathematicks. For eeing that the Specifick Virtues of each Medicines which enter into the Compoition, remain in it after the los of their firt qualities,
when they are received in the Stomach, as in a Natural place, every kind, without mixing one with another, and confounding their Beams, tends to that part to which it is affected, and hath correpondency with, and with their Actinobolim, do wonderfully trengthen and comfort it. Whence cometh, that all the Members being comforted, the Natural heat mut alo of neceity be trengthned; and the more it is, the les power will the Dieae have; inomuch, that we may imagine in Phyick as many Centers of Virtues as there be Individuals that compound it; and if there be many Cordials mixed together, they all hall cat their Beams upon the Heart: Thoe Herbs that have relation to the Lungs, hall work that way, and the Hepatical ones, hall all tend to comfort the Liver. And thus by the Aggregation of o many Virtues, the Body mut of neceity prevail againt the Dieae: So contrariwie, that Antipathetical Actinobolim which proceedeth from poyons, and poyonous things, aoon as it is got down into the Stomach, doth firt attack the Heart, as the fortres of the Body. Thus the Mineral Poyons, as, Arenick, Orpine, Ochra, and the Poyons of Serpents, by their radiation, infect the next Blood, and that the next, and o conequently,
till it hath reached to the Heart. Whence if it be not expelled by the Antactinobolim of ome counterpoyon it bringeth detruction to the party: Beides that, every Member hath its peculiar Poyons; for ome do not attack the Heart immediately, but the Lungs. As, that Zoophyte, called Pulmo Marinus, which being eaten, ulcerateth the Lungs, and bringeth the party into a low Conumption. The Sardonian Smallage, as alo that Inect called Tarantola, invading the S • ats of the Spirits, and the Arteries and Mucles, provoketh a Man to laughing and dancing. The biting of the Serpent called Dypas, as oon as it beginneth to diffue, doth by its Radiation bring the Liver into Putrefraction. The biting of a Mad-Dog giveth to a Man the Dogs manners; for he continually barketh, biteth, and feareth Water. The biting of a Mad-Cat, imparteth the Cats manners. Skenkius relateth of a Maid that had eaten of a Cats Brains, and did perfectly imitate a Cats manners, expreing its voice, and hunting after Mice with her crooked Fingers and Nails. The Poyon of an Ap being an enemy to the Nerves, doth by its Radiation caue a udden lack of Sene in all the Limbs which it corrupteth. The biting of the Serpent (called for that reaon Haemorrhois) by its
Radiation turneth all the Humors of the Body into Blood, as Generus witneeth, Lib. 5. Hit. Anim. Which is confirmed by Lucretius in his Ninth Book, by thee excellent Veres.

q.l: tque olet pariter totis e effundere venis
Corycii preura croci: Sic omnia membra
Emiere imul rutilum pro anguine virus.
Humor, ab iis largus manat cruor: Ora redundant
Et patulae nares, udor rubet, omnia plenis,
Membra fluunt venis: Totum et pro vulnere corpus.

div.p:
We may ee by thee and everal other Experiments, which I omit for brevities ake, that the everal Members and Parts of the Body have their everal Subtances, which do not work by their proper Poyons, but by the Diffuion of their Radiant Virtues; which cannot be remedied, but by the Radiation of contrary Subtances which detroy thoe venemous qualities, even as the hadows and darknees cannot be detroyed but by the
Radiation of Light. From all thee things it is evident, that there is nothing in Nature without that virtue of Radiation, inerted by the Author of Nature, for thoe ends bet known to himelf, and in imitation of the Light, inomuch, that the Judicious Reader, by this Doctrine of Actinobolims, and that of Magnetims, may as with two Wings oar to the highet knowledge of Natural things. He that will be further atisfied in examples of that nature, let him read Skenkius de Venenis.

To thee mut be added what we have aid before, to wit, That the Specifick Virtues of each Medicine that enters into a compoition, remain in it after the los of their firt qualities which may be proved by this Experiment.

Take Nettles, dry them, and burn them to ahes, make Lees of thoe ahes; expoe the Lees in the night to the Air, till it be covered with an Icy thin Skin, and you hall ee in that Skin the perfect figure of a Nettle, with the tretching of its fibers and jagged Leaves, as if it were a Natural one; and if you look upon it with a Magnifying Glas, you hall perceive with admiration all the
• igure of the Nettle, grown out of mall and
• lmot infinite number of mall Cellules. Th
ame will happen in any other Plant, to hew that no Seed can be o exactly mixed with other things, but it will retain and affect till its own Nature. All this that we have aid, tendeth to hew how Coral bringeth to pas all thoe wonderful Virtues we have attributed to it. Thoe that hall deire to be better atisfied in this Doctrine of Actinobolim and Radiation, let them eriouly meditate the Platical Virtue of all Seeds, in which, being eated in the abtruet parts of the Body, doth without any tools or noie, produce a work o wonderful in variety and comlines of Parts, and that, out of a rough and inform matter, in which there is no ditinction of parts, nor variety that may be oberved by the Senes. For we ee that in the Seed, without any appearance lieth and lurketh the whole Tree, with the Roots, the Body, the Boughs, the Leaves, and the Fruits. Out of one Corn of Wheat, proceedeth the Root, the Stalk, the Ear, and the Corn. In an Egg, which is the Seed of Birds, lurketh the whole Bird, with all, and every one of its Limbs, and all the differences of its colours. In the Seed lieth the Body of the Animals with all its Limbs, the Heart, the Brains, the Lungs, the Liver, the Spleen, the Stomach, the Kidneys, the Bladder, the Nerves, Tendons,
Mucles, Veins, Arteries, &c. Every one of which hath its proper and certain figure, its colour, and proprieties. Who evereth o many various things hidden in an Homogeneal Body, who eparateth an uniform Matter into Bones, Humors, Fleh, Gritles? &c. None other certainly, but that Platical Virtue which the Almighty hath inerted into all things that were to be propagated by Generation. This Virtue giveth to every Limb its due cituation, colour, figure, proportion, and quality: By its workmanhip the Body is hollowed into o many Pipes, Chanels, Paages, and Meanders. Therefore, we uppoe, that the ame Platical Virtue, is diffued in all the parts of the Seed: So that it is all in all, and all in every part of the Seed.

The reaon is, That the Productions are ometimes but one, and ometimes many; and that the Production that cometh from one part of the Seed, is no les perfect than that which cometh from the whole: And finally, that there is no confuion nor inordination of parts, which of neceity hould happen, if it were not uniform with the Subject; for if one part of the Seed were taken away, one part of the Production hould alo be wanting. And thus hould
happen a Confuion in the Figure by the tranpoition of the parts: And although the Seed, in order to the Senes, eem to have no ditinct and heterogeneal parts; nevertheles, being conidered in it elf, it hath: Seeing that it is not a ingle, but a Body compounded of many; for that part of the Platick Virtue which frameth the Brains, hall not frame the Heart or the Liver; and that part which hath framed the Bones, hall not tretch the Membranes, or dipoe the Guts into a winding compas. The only difficulty is, Why that Platick Virtue, which is o confuedly mixed, yet, worketh without confuion, and dipoeth of all things with an admirable order, and as the Greeks call it
< in non-Latin alphabet > .

But this concerning not our Subject at preent, we pas it over, being contented to have tirred up the curious Reader to the Meditation and Study of the Magnetims and Actinobolims, in which he hall find matter enough to atisfie himelf in the proces of Nature, and in the admiration and love of the Creator. But this digreion hath paed a little already the bounds of our Subject, let us go back from whence we came.

We conclude then, That the Tincture of Coral being ep • rated from the Body of it;
the pure from the impure; the formal from the material; the Celetial from the Terretrial, it worketh by its A •• inobolim or Radiation, and its Magnetim; by which it is Analogal to the Heart, the Fountain of Life, thoe wonderful Effects we have made mention of, we will decend to ome particular Intances.

div.head: CHAP. VI.
Of the Virtues of the Tincture of Coral, in the Curing of all Malignant and Petilential Feavers.
div.p: WE give this intance firt, as the mot coniderable, and of greatet concernment. Thee Feavers under the notion and name of a Cold, having detroyed o many of late, that a Body cannot without grief, and a certain horror, read the increae of the Bill of Mortality upon this particular point, while the Patients flatter themelves that it is nothing but a Cold; and the Phyicians, either by ignorance, wilfulnes, or mutual Envy, precribe Bleeding, Purging, Blitering, and uch other dangerous and prepoterous means; which though they may ometimes be ued in other Feavers, yet in this are they Mortal.

As firt for Bleeding, it hath always been condemned by the mot judicious in Malignant and Petilential Dieaes, by reaon that it weakneth Nature, by exhauting the Blood wherein the Life coniteth, by diminihing the Spirits which are the tie of the Soul with
the Body, and by uffering the venemous quality to rage the more by ubtracting that weet and Natural Juyce, which was rather to be incouraged for the taming and allaying of it.

Purging is neither to be admitted, unles there be an extraordinary fulnes of Humors, it being ufficient to keep the Body oluble; as alo, becaue in thoe Feavers there is commonly a perturbation of Humors, which Purging cannot egregate, till they be perfectly concocted, and appear o by the Urines, and the lacking of the bad Symptoms. Concocta medicari oportet non cruda, aith Hippocrates.

As little ignificant as thee, is the new way they go about by Blitering; for whereas this Petilential Feaver hath its eat in the Spirits, what communion is there between their Malignity and Bliters, which do not reach beyond the skin, et the whole frame of Nature in torture and anguih, and cut the troath of the Patient before the Wounds can be cicratrized? This practice eeming only invented to beget Apothecaries practie and Phyicians omewhat to ay, when they are at their wits end.

Now nothing remaineth to overcome o powerful an enemy but Cordials, o called, becaue, without doing any violence to Nature,
<1 page duplicate>
<1 page duplicate>
or weakening her trength, they directly go to the Heart, chear it up, fight againt the malignity; and as a Light dipereth darknes, o do thee, any thing that is enemy to Mans life. Which being done, that wholome temper, in which coniteth Life and Health, taketh place again, and the Patient is retored to his former tate.

Under that name of Cordials, every one almot obtrudeth what his own fancy and imagination thinketh, or hath heard to be o, though it be but a imple Ditilled Water, coloured with ome Sirrup; and thus trifle away the mot precious thing of the World, which is time (as C • eiphon aith) while the malignity gets footing, and never ceaeth till it hath detroyed the Patient.

Now, as we do not deny that there is abundance of thoe Remedies called Cordials, in Nature; o we deny that it is every ones Talent to know them, or the ue of them, or the preparation of them. As for example, What good can be expected from the Water of a Plant Ditilled in a Mettallick Furnace, having been firt irrorated or teeped in common Water, that the greater quantity may be drawn, as it is now commonly practied. Beides the inconveniency of the Metallick quality of the Limbeck which communicateth
it elf to the Water, as it is evidently een, and have often tried my elf: For having occaion everal times to precribe Mineral Waters, as that of Epom, Tunbridge, &c. to everal Patients, and among them, to my own Daughter. It fell out, that the Water which was brought from the Wells in Bottles, did agree very well with them, and wrought effectually without any violence; but when, by the want of that, I was forced to make ue of that which they fell in Town, and keep in Leaden Citerns, I found a contrary effect; for it wrought o untowardly, that it frighted me every time; which I could attribute to nothing ele, but to the poyonous quality of the Lead, of which the Citerns were made, and in which the Waters were kept. By this we ee what a neceary thing it is, in uch caes, and many others, That a Phyician hould be his own Apothecary; and this I peak meerly for the interet of the truth, being not ignorant how many intereed perons will contradict it.

Having et down all thee Notions, it is alo requiite we hould et down the ue of our Tincture of Coral; therefore aoon as one falleth into that Malignant or Petilential Feaver, which is known chiefly by the malnes, quicknes, and intermittency of the
Pule, let him go to Bed in a warm Room, and being well covered to weat, let him drink one doe of our Tincture of Coral, weating after, as long as he is a able; and let him follow exactly the method we have et down in our Book of the lat great Plague, Anno 1665. The particulars of which concerning this, we hall repeat here, becaue the Book is hard to be had, there having been three Impreions dipered in ix weeks time, and none to be had at preent, that I know: Therefore I hall repeat to this purpoe, only the XXX. XXXI. XXXII. XXXIII. XXXIV. XXXV. XXXVI. Aphorimes mutatis mutandis.

div.head: XXX.
div.p:
Aoon as any one findeth himelf tricken with any of thee Symptoms, to wit, a Headake, Vomiting, Faintnes, Looenes, and a mall quick and intermitting Pule, without any prejacent or evident caue, let him preently repair to a clean and warm Room, and let a light fire of Wood be kindled in the Chimney, to conume and detroy all the infectious vapors that proceed both from the Air, and the infected party. Let the Patient be preently put into a warm Bed himelf, wrapped in a Sheet and Blanket, having
firt put off his Shirt, that when he cometh to be dried, you may not be put to the trouble of pulling off his wet Shirt, then give him one doe of our Tincture of Coral, and covering him with Cloaths very warm all over, leaving only his repiration free, and putting a warm Brick to the Soles of his Feet, and another to his Knees; let him weat as long as he is able, or at leat, for the pace of three or four hours, and be not afraid he hould faint, if he hath breath enough.

div.head: XXXI.
div.p: If it hould happen, as it doth commonly to thoe that are firt taken with a vomiting, that the Patient hould cat up the Cordial, you mut give him another doe; and if he hould cat up this alo, give him a third, and o continue till till he keepeth it once, for he will never cat it up afterwards; and though he hould, yet by having taken it o often, ome of the qualities of it will remain behind, that will work their effect.

div.head: XXXII.
div.p:
Children that cannot or will not take the Remedy, mut be compelled to it by pouring it into their Throat with an Intrument, called by the Greeks
< in non-Latin alphabet > , which is a kind of
Spoon with a cover, having a pout to put into the Mouth, and o to pour it down.

div.head: XXXIII.
div.p: The Patient having weated three or four hours, the more the better, you mut give him a little more breath, and began to take off the Cloaths by degrees; and when you have dried him very well with warm Cloaths (which all this while mut hang by the fire with his Shirt) then pull away the wet Sheet and Blanket from under him, then give him his Shirt, and after that, dry his Head, and take heed, by all means, that any cold Air hould come into the Room. After you have dried his Head ufficiently, and that the party beginneth to be cool, give him to drink leiurely, two ounces of our Cordial Water, decribed in the aid Book of the Plague, which is of an admirable virtue in this cae, and alo in Faintnees, Surfeittings, and Poyons, This will refreh him o peedily and wonderfully, that he will preently forget the tireomnes of his weating.

div.head: XXXIV.
div.p:
When he is quite cold, give him to eat any thing he hath a mind to; o that it be of good Juyce, and eaie digetion: Let his
drink be trong Beer, lukewarm, or ome Generous Claret Wine; for, as we have aid before, this Feaver differeth from all others. And whereas in others we ubtract Meat, and trong Drink, as much as we can, we mut in this allow them, it being only a malignant quality, in which, good Meat and Drink cannot hurt, but rather allay it, as alo becaue the Patient would not be able to weat twice a day in this manner (which of neceity he mut do, if he will ave his life) unles his trength be repaired with good nutriment.

div.head: XXXV.
div.p: This coure of Sweating twice a day, mut be continued for four days together or five at the mot, in which pace of time, all the Malignity and Petilential Poyon will expire; and, if this be carefully done, and attended, there is no Malignant or Petilential Feaver o tubborn of any kind whatoever, but mut yield.

div.head: XXXVI.
div.p:
Although the danger be over in four days, yet will it not be amis to make ue till of Cordials now and then; for it is not only neceary to dive away the Petilential Poyon, but alo to trengthen the noble parts,
upon which it may have made an impreion, the malignity of a thing being not only in the Caue, but alo in the parts to whom the caue did adhere.
Thus much have I trancribed out of my Book of the Plague, for the eae and conveniency of the Reader, and for the advancing the ue of o noble a Remedy, as the Tincture of Coral.

Now eeing that this Tincture is to be adminitred with our admirable Water againt the Plague, and Malignant Feavers, and that the Subtance of both is more formal then material, not lating long in the Body; therefore the doe is to be renewed every day, allowing about three hours of Interval between every doe, beides one doe in the night, if the Patient awakes. If this be carefully done, there is no Malignant Dieae but may be cured.

But as a Gardner that will carefully bring up a Plant, taketh care to weed it often, let it hould be choaked or want nourihment. So that I may how the beauty of this Remedy, I mut extirpate everal Weeds that have crept in of late into the Family of Remedies, to the deluion of the Patients, and the irriion of ignorant Phyicians.

div.head: CHAP. VII.
Of the dangerous and poyonous quality and ue of Blitering Playters, and that they ought to be exterminated out of the Number and Family of Remedies.
div.p:
MAny times when a Phyician is at his wits end, and hath nothing to ay more concerning the Dieae in hand, he precribeth Blitering, not knowing nor ditinguihing whether it will be fitting or not. And there is ome policy in that too; for beides the obligation, he layeth upon h • s Friend the Apothecary, himelf is not without hope of benefit, and of being ent for, the more often whiles the wounds are green; but what good this can do, or which way, chiefly in a Malignant Feaver, you mut not ask, for himelf cannot tell, but only, that it is the common practice of the Town. Which, if it be a atisfactory anwer, let every body judge. If this abue had been harmles, I would have paed over it, as I do over many others that I know, and do only range among the
Vulgar Errors. But eeing it tendeth to the detruction of mankind, as I have een by many ad and woful experiences, and hall prove by many grave and Authentical Authors, I hould in againt my Concience, Reaon, Knowledge, and Experience, if I did not lay open the cheat thereof, in favor of a gallant Nation, among which I live and am o humanely protected.

Be it known therefore, that there is a Remedy now practied in Phyick called by the Greeks
< in non-Latin alphabet > from the Verb < in non-Latin alphabet > , which in Latine ignifieth Attraho, in Englih, to draw or attract, which was invented by the Ancients, chiefly to comfort the weaknes of thoe parts which come by cold, or too much moiture, whence it is evident, that all thoe Remedies are exceeding hot, dry, and harp. Of thee orts are Mutard-Seed, Thapia, Goats Dung, Crees-Seed, Eliampanes Roots, the Sea Onion, Pigeons Dung, Mice Dung, Lice-Bean, Cantharides, and uch like; of which, at preent the Modern Phyicians, and namely the Dipenatory of London, have framed a Plaiter for that purpoe, called Emplatrum Epipaticon, of which, here is the decription.

div.head: Emplatrum Epipaticum.
div.p: R. Sinapeas.
Eupborbii.
Piperis longi ana drachmam unam emis:
Staphiagriae.
Pyrethri, ana drachmas duas.
Gummi Ammoniaci.
Galbani.
Bdellii.
Sagapeni, ana drachmas tres.
Cantharidum integrarum drachmas quinque.
Picis navalis.
Reinae.
Cerae citrinae ana drachmas ex.
Terebinthinae, quantum ufficit, fiat Emplatrum uui reponendum.

Now, as I will not deny but that Plaiter may be ueful in ome caes, if it be judiciouly applied; o I affirm, that it is of a dangerous efficacy, if it be miapplied, and chiefly upon tender Bodies, extenuated by Sicknes, Fating, Watching, and Pains; the Reaon is, That the Cantharides or Spanih Flies, which are the Bais of it, are a mot deadly Poyon, and a particular enemy to the Bladder and Genital Parts, which is
o much the more prevalent, in that ome Apothecaries of their own accord to make the Plaiter of a more quick working, have augmented the doe of the Cantharides. So that when this Plaiter is applied to one ick of a Malignant Feaver, and already extenuated with the dieae of Fating and Watching, he hath good luck if he ecape with life. Thoe that are for it, may chance to urge their own experience, againt which I hall oppoe mine, which is of forty years tanding; but becaue neither they or I hould be believed, as being Partial, I hall cite here ome memorable obervations made by everal learned, honet, and famous Authors, to clear this point, which is of o great a conequence.

I hall not peak here of the dangers and cruel Symptoms that follow the taking of Cantharides inwardly, becaue they are o generally known, that no body can be ignorant thereof, but thoe that are altogether ignorant of Phyick, I hall only mention the pernicious effects, and ad conequences they caue, being applied outwardly. The firt Obervation hall be taken out of Guilielmus Fabricius Hildanus, a late Author, and excellent Phyician and Chirurgeon in Switzerland, in his Ninety and eighth Obervation.

A certain Gentleman of the Town of Villeneuve, by the Lake of Geneva, having a cold Tumor in one of his Knees, caued by a cold, and tough Humor, did ask a Barbers advice, who without taking notice of the Antecedent Caue, went about to cure him only with Topical Remedies; therefore he applied firt Cupping Glaes, after that a Cautery on the ide of the Kneepan, thinking to empty the Matter that was gathered. When thee did not ucceed, he applied a Pultes made with Leaven and Cantharides, and did exulcerate all the Knee, then followed an exceive pain about the Knee, retlenes, a Feaver, and everal other fearful Symptoms; among which, was a grievous pain of the Reins, and of all the Belly, and preently after uch a heat in his Urine, that he could not make one drop (for it came only drop by drop, and that Bloody) without the greatet torture imaginable. The Pultes being removed, he was omething the better, becaue it had drawn the mot ubtle part of the Humor: Which when the Barber aw, he applied again the ame Pultes of Cantharides, upon which all the aid Symptoms became wore than before, and chiefly the heat of Urine, which the Patient feeling would admit no more of the aid Pultes, but dimit
his Barber, and after came to me to Lauanna
where having prepared firt his Body with opening Apozemes, I purged him everal times with the aggregative Pills, and thoe of Her modacts; and after that, gave him the decoction of Guaiacum, Saafras, and China, cauing him to weat gently, that the Matter about the Knee might melt and evaporate, after that I applied this Pultes of Vigo.

. Farinae Fabarum.
Farinae hordei, an. iv.
Furfuris bene triturati M. ij.
Stercoris Caprini triturati lb. s.
Meliloti an. m. 1. cum Lixivio & Sapa ufficienti de omnibus fiat Emplatrum olidum addendo olei Camomelini & Anethini ana ij, applicetur calide bis in die.
When he had ued this Pultes a whole moneth together, he recovered his health. You hall find the like example in Joh. Langius, Lib. 1. Epit. 47.

The third Obervation hall be taken out of Baccius, in Prolegomenis Venenorum & Antidotorum, where he aith, We find by Experience, that Cantharides being mixed in Blitering Plaiters, and applied, do mot violently corrode the Stomach and the Belly; but above all, to be by its property a peculiar enemy to the Bladder, and to tear it in pieces with its Bloody rine, and o to kill the Patients. For
we have oberved many times, that when Cantharides have been applied to the Head in a Lethargy, and to the Brawns of the Arms and Legs; they have caued an extream pain, with an inflammation and difficulty of Bloody rine, and o have killed the Patients. Which danger deerves a erious conideration.

The fourth Obervation is out of Braavolus, Comm. ad Aphor. 17. Lib. 2. who aith, That one Vincentinus Grema, a famous Chirurgeon in his time, took once a Medicine, the Powders of which had been tamped in a Morter, where Cantharides, had been tamped before: Whereupon, though he did not actually eat any Cantharides, yet was he excoriated from the Mouth to the Fundament, and could not get his health again in les then eighteen Moneths pace; yet were there no Cantharides in the cae, but a kind of quality proceeding from them that tuck about the Morter.

The fifth Obervation is out of Bartholomeus Montagnana, a famous Phyician of Italy, who relateth, That one Francis Brac, a Citizen of Padua, having applied ome Cantharides to his Knee, did avoid by Urine above Five pounds of Blood; and that the ame did happen to one who applied them to his great Toe, to take away the roughnes and unevennes
of his Nails. Langius, Tom. 1. Epit. 47.

But what is more incredible then this is, That a certain Chirurgeon of Milan, made twice Bloody water, for carrying in his Pocket a Veicatory made of Cantharides. Thus affirmeth, Joan. Michael Pachalius, Method. Curand. Morb. cap. 44.

The ixth Obervation is of a certain Man who carrying by chance Cantharides in his Pocket, as the fahion is of ome Chirurgeons, did make Bloody Urine; and complaining to me of it, I bid him he hould not meddle with them, no not o much as to touch them, or carry them in his Pocket. Such another accident, I was told by Helidaeus de Paduinis, a famous Phyician of Bolonia, with whom I ued to viit ick people, when I was at Bolonia. The mot famous Phyician Adolphus Occo in his Obervations.

The eventh Obervation is of a Noble Woman who having her Face full of red, burning, and ugly Pimples, was o deformed therewith, that every Body avoided her as a Leper, and the Magitrates were ready to equeter her from the common ociety of Mankind. She came to Paris, where having called for two Doctors of Phyick, to wit, Hollerius and Grealmus, and two Chirurgeons Mr. Cabal,
and my elf, he inquired with great care and diligence, if there was no remedy againt uch a deformity. Having conidered diligently the dieae, we unanimouly concluded that it was no Leproie, but that it was fitting that a Veicatory made of Cantharides hould be applied all the Face over, three or four hours after her Bladder began to ake, and to burn vehemently, and the Neck of the Womb, to well with gripings, a continual vomiting, and making of water, a raving carriage of all her Limbs, and a Burning Feaver. I called for the Phyicians again preently; the concluion was, That we hould give her much Milk to drink, and inject ome in the Guts by the Fundament, and into the Womb and Bladder by the rethra; that he hould go into a lukewarm Bath, wherein hould have been boiled Lineeds, the Roots and Leaves of Mallows and Marh-Mallows, of Violets, Hemlock, Purleine, and Lettice; and o to continue, from time to time, till the pain was quite ceaed. That the Reins and Genital Parts hould be anointed with nguentum Roatum and Populeon, diolved and mixed with Oxycrat. By thee means all the Symptomes vanihed away, in the mean time the Face was full of Bliters, which being broke, a great deal of Matter iued out,
and the deformity was cured, inomuch, that a little while after he was married, and had many Children. Ambroius Paraeus, Lib. 5. cap. 17.

For my own part I can certifie, that my younget Daughter Elizabeth, being about thirteen or fourteen years old, and very ubject to ore eyes; after I had purged her, and let her blood in the foot, I applied a Veicatory of Cantharides, at the bottom of her neck, thinking to make a diverion of the Humor, but within three or four hour after he fell tark lame of her right hip, o that I was forced preently to remove the Veicatory; and for all that, the lamenes continued three or four weeks after. By what I have aid, it is apparent what a dangerous thing Cantharides is, not only inwardly given, in which cae they are a deadly poyon, but alo outwardly applied; as is een by the everal Obervations I have made here, and many more may be taken out of Foretus, Cabrolius, &c.

I could alo here relate ome fatal Obervations of my own, and of which, I have been a ad eye-witnes; but that I do not love to renew the grief of the living Relations, nor to inult on the micarriage of Phyicians, knowing that we are all faulty, and
that againt death we have no power but forgetfulnes.
From thee things we may perceive the truth of what Mathiolus aith upon the Sixth Book of Diocorides, where he hath thee words.

Cantharides are hurtful chiefly to the Bladder, and to all the parts that erve for the evacuation of rine, not only being taken inwardly, but alo being applied outwardly where there is occaion to Bliter, chiefly when they are mixed with large Pultees, and are applied to places near the Bladder, to wit, the Hips, the Privy Parts, the Kidneys, or the Stones. Thus far Mathiolus.

Therefore if any Body will make ue of them, it is neceary he hould do it prudently and circumpectly, chiefly let the young Phyicians take heed, leat in precribing Remedies which admit of Cantharides, they do not err in quantity; for becaue Cantharides are o light, that fifty of them weigh carce one drachm, the Error is eaie to be committed. Nay, the mot ingenuous of the Apothecaries have confeed to me, that in the Dipenation of their Emplatrum Epipaticon, they double the doe of Cantharides to make it of a quicker working. Who hall be o bold after this, to make ue of o pernicious a Remedy,
and chiefly in Malignant Feavers, where the Poyon is inward, the Vitals dejected, the Natural trength abated, and no good can be alledged to come out of this Remedy? All the excue being, that it is a common practice about the Town, that is, a common and a pernicious Vulgar Error. Away then with thoe dangerous things, more petilent many times then the dieae it elf; and let us turn our practie to a afer and nobler way, that is, our Tincture of Coral, which without danger, but rather with a great deal of pleaure, performeth in Malignant Feavers, and other dieaes, we have or hall mention, the three o much required Indications, for the relief of the Patient, and the honor of the Phyician, to wit, Cito, tuto, jucunde.

div.head: CHAP. VIII.
Of the Virtue of the Tincture of Coral, in all Feavers and Agues.
div.p: I Have ranged thee two Dieaes under one Head, becaue they are of the ame Nature, except that Feavers are continual, and Agues intermittent, but both to be cured the ame way.

I am not here to expres the Nature of all Feavers, which belongeth to the general knowledge of Phyick, and would well this little Treatie into a Volume, but to touch as much of them as will erve our own intention, and to hew how the Tincture of Coral is, and may be a Sovereign Remedy for them: Therefore leaving aides their everal Definitions, Diviions, and Controveries, we hall only mark the chief Grounds of their Nature, and the Analogy that is between it and their Remedy, to wit, The Tincture of Coral.

Firt then let it be etablihed, that a Feaver is a hot intempery proceeding from a Preternatural heat kindled in the Heart; and from thence dipered into all the Body, by the
means of the Veins and Arteries, and hurting the Natural Actions. The chief Indication for the curing of them, is to take away that Preternatural heat, and to reduce the Body into its former temper, as we ee, that all things after they have left their boiling and fermenting, and are cooled, become purer then they were before. Wherein it is to be oberved, that the Natural heat, and the Preternatural, differ chiefly in this, That the Natural heat is a Subtance, and the Preternatural only a Quality. The ignorance of this difference is the caue, that o many micarry in Feavers; for when Phyicians go about that Preternatural heat (uppoe by Bleeding) they altogether quench the Natural one, which by all means ought to be preerved, and o haten the Diolution of the Patient, by taking away the Bais, upon which, Life is founded: For what need is it, if one deireth to take away the Preternatural heat, and o to cure a Feaver, that he hould alo take with it the Natural one, in which coniteth a Mans life; for the Preternatural heat being once removed, the other remaineth free for the exerciing harmonically the Functions of the Body. The only eaie, and ure way therefore to cure Feavers, is to extinguih the Preternatural heat, without doing prejudice
to the Natural one, but rather comforting and trengthning it.

Now I affirm, that this cannot be done afely but by eparating the Preternatural heat from the Natural; and o expelling the Preternatural, while the Natural remaineth in liberty, to perform the Functions of Nature; which being helped by noble and harmles Remedies, will quickly and afely disburden her elf of what is noxious and purious, as we have hewed before in the example of Anelmus de Booth: And this by an Univeral Evacuation thorough the Pores, becaue the dieae is univerally dipered thorough the whole Body; which by this means is not only lightned of its burden, but comforted and trengthned by the virtue and efficacy of this noble Remedy.

It is alo to be oberved, That the Natural heat is Celetial, as flowing from the Sun, Sol & homo generant hominem, and the Preternatural, is Elementary; and therefore eaily eparable from the other: But ome Body will object perhaps, that beides the Preternatural heat which makes a Feaver, there may be mixed with it a Latent Malignity, and ask what hall become of it? I anwer, That the Preternatural heat, and the Malignity go away together in the Evacuation; for the way
way through the Pores, being free and open, and this Remedy being one of the mot powerful Cordials in the World, driveth away from the Heart, that is, from the Center to the Circumference, whatoever is an Enemy to the Humane Body, and that with a great deal of eae and ecurity.

Now concerning thoe Feavers called Intermittent, or as the vulgar termeth them, Agues, the Method and Remedy is the ame, except that the Salt of Coral mut be mixed with the Tincture, becaue thee Agues have their foundation in a toughter matter then the Feavers, to wit, in the Humors; as the Tertian in Choler, the Quotidian in Phlegm, the Quartan in Melancholy, wherein they harbor, as in their proper Ferment, which they will hardly forake till it be detroyed. Now the Tincture of Coral alone, being too Formal and Spiritual to detroy and dipere thoe earthly droes, we in this cae joyn with it the Salt, which cutteth and incieth the toughnes of the matter and denity, and prepareth it to expulion, when the Tincture cometh to radiate upon it.

I have thus a little inlarged my elf upon this ubject of Feavers, becaue there is no dieae more vulgar and frequent; for eeing that mot of other dieaes do not eie upon
Humane Bodies equally, but are more or les familiar to ome Ages, Regions, and Contitutions of Bodies then others; there is no Age, Region, and Contitution of Body, that can promie to it elf a freedom from Feaver; and, as it is a frequent dieae, o is it mot dangerous, and not without caue: For it occupieth the Storehoue of the Natural and Vivifying heat, wateth and detroyeth it, and unles that Fiery and Preternatural heat be timely prevented, it cattereth and devoureth the Natural one; which being the Treaure of Life, Death is preently at the door, inomuch, that mot people die of that dieae; or rather, as Galen aith, Nemo ine febre moritur, No Body dies without a Feaver; which is the reaon, that the Ancient Romans having a mind to court it, and to render it propitious unto themelves, did build it a Temple and Worhipped it upertitiouly as a Goddes; as Plinius affirmeth, Lib. 2. cap. 24. Augut. de Civit. Dei, Lib. 2. cap. 14. And Val. Max. Lib. 2. cap. 5.

div.head: CHAP. IX.
How the Tincture of Coral worketh upon all thoe other Dieaes, we have aid it was fit for.
div.p:
WE have here and there mentioned everal Dieaes; in which we affirm the Tincture of Coral to be a mot Sovereign Remedy; and that not only out of our own experience, but out of the Authority of famous and learned Men in all Ages, as
Diocorides.
Mathiolus.
Anelmus de Booth.
Owaldus Crollius.
Joannes Petrus Faber.
Arnoldus Villanovanus.
Forretus.
Fernelius.
Cardanus.
Rogerius Baco.

And as many others as have written of the Nature and Virtues of Coral, who agree all in one, and by that means have made it an undeniable truth. It will not be amis now by way of Recapitulation to mention all thoe
Dieaes again, and to illutrate as much as in us lieth, the way and manner how the Tincture of Coral worketh upon them.

list.head: The Dieaes againt which the Tincture of Coral is a Sovereign Remedy.
list.item: All immoderate Fluxes in Women, whether Red or White.
All Bloody Fluxes, Gripings, and Lasks.
Spitting of Blood, and the Piles.
Intemperies of the Liver, Spleen, and Kidneys.

div.head: Againt the Plague.
div.p: It worketh both by its Elementary and Specifick qualiies; for while by its excellent temper it bringeth all the Humors into a perfect Crais, and union, and quelleth all the Jars that are among them; the Formal part of it, in which lies the Specifick quality doth by its Actinobolim or Irradiation, expel all the Malignancy and Poyon of the Air thorough the Pores, by cating the Patient into a gentle and moderate weat, and trengthning the noble Parts.

div.head: Againt Feavers and Agues.
div.p: It worketh the ame way, and beides it detroyeth and cattereth the Ferment, in which lieth the form of the Feaver, and the type of the Ague.

div.head: Againt the Flux, Small Pox, and Meales.
div.p:
Thee Dieaes being naturally rooted in the Body, as a part and portion of the impurity of the Mentrual Blood, which is the reaon that all mankind is liable to it once in its life, ooner or later, and may be called The original • n of the Body, or as Avicenna calleth it, Morbus Mentrui. This noble Remedy cleaneth all thoe Impurities by eparating the pure from the impure, which it thruteth away from the Center to the Circumference
thorough the Pores; and o comforteth the noble Parts.

div.head: Againt all immoderate Fluxes in Women.
div.p: It worketh by its Specifick quality of corroborating the Liver and Spleen, the Intempery of which is the Antecedent and chief au e of all thee diorders.

div.head: Againt all Bloody Fluxes, Gripings, and Lasks.
div.p: There being uch a ympathy between Humane Blood, and the Tincture of Coral, it is not hard to gues, that in this cae it worketh by the amity and friendhip they have together; by which the Blood is cheered up, and, as it were, courted to remain in its Receptacles and Veels; by which means, and the trengthning of the Vitals, all the Preternatural ymptoms ceae.

div.head: Againt Spitting of Blood, and the Piles.
div.p: All thee kinds of Haemorrhagies proceeding from a Vein that is either broken, corroded, or gaping, it is apparent, that no better Remedy can be given then the Tincture of Coral, given in a proper Vehioulum, having manifet Qualities for the healing of the Veins, and Specifick ones for the tanching of the Blood; and it is agreed by all Authors.

div.head: Againt the Fits of the Mother.
div.p:
Seeing that this Dieae called by the Latins
teri Suffocatio, hath more everal Caues then can at this time be eaily expreed. We hall only ay, That the Tincture of Coral being minitred in a proper Vehicle, cattereth all thoe noxious fumes; and by its Radiation, penetrates as far as to the eat of the ditemper, and trengthneth all the Vitals.

div.head: Againt Dropies.
div.p: It is known to every Body that mot Dropies come by an Intempery of the Liver or Spleen; which is viibly and palpably rectified by this noble Remedy, having firt purged and emptied the uperfluous Matter.

div.head: Againt the Convulion.
div.p: This Dieae being mot frequent among Children, and proceeding from the Malignant Vapors of the Body, which vellicate and pluck the Nerves, is cured by the Irradiation and Specifick quality of this Remedy.

div.head: Againt the Palie.
div.p: The Palie being an abolihing of the Motion, and ometime of the Sene, caued by the want of the Animal Spirits, which are neceary for the free motion of the Body, is helped by this Remedy; which openeth obtructions, dilateth the paages, quickneth the Animal Spirits, and makes them fit for Radiation.

div.head: Againt the Falling Sicknes.
div.p: The Epilepie or Falling Sicknes, is an often tretching of the Body, or a hort Convulion, by which a Man falleth down on a udden, without Sene or Motion; o that he neither heareth nor eeth, nor remembreth any thing that is pat in the Fit, when he is out of it. In the agitation they foam at the Mouth, and the Mucles being looe, either the Urine, or Dung, or Seed. cometh out involuntarily. This being caued by a Malignant Vapor which proceedeth from either the Brains, the Stomach, or ome particular part of the Body, is cured by the Tincture of Coral, given in Paeony Water, after the neceary Evacuations.

div.head: Againt the Stone and Gravel.
div.p: In this ditemper we give both the Tincture and the Salt; that while the Tincture comforteth the noble Parts, the Salt by its opening and diuretick faculty may wate and break to pieces whatoever is of Stone or Gravel.

div.head: Againt lcers.
div.p:
Ulcers being either inward or outward, the inward ones are cured by the taking of the aid Tincture in a proper Vehicle; and the outward ones, be they never o malignant, are cured by the outward application of it; for it
correcteth all malignity, and cicatrizeth them, even to admiration.

div.head: Againt the Pleuriie.
div.p: It hath been a general opinion, that a Pleuriie cannot be cured without Blood-letting but give me leave to tell you, That in my forty years experience and practice, I have een more miearry by that way, then aved; unles the Body be extraordinarily Plethorical, and the Pleuriie exceeding violent the reaon is, that ubtracting the Blood, you exhaut the Treaure of Life. So that many times, the Patient cannot lat till Suppuration, for want of trength and o drops by the way before he can reach home. Add to this, that the Feaver which is an ineparable companion of the Pleuriie, is not o oon extinguihed this way as it is cattered into everal Particles, by this noble Remedy, while the Fomentations dicus the eat of the ditemper, and awage the pain and other ymptoms, and proper Pultees utterly diipate the Impothume.

div.head: Againt Barrennes in Women.
div.p:
There being divers and almot innumerable Caues of Barrennes, we do not pretend here to hooe every foot by the ame Lat; we know that ome of the Caues may belong to Chirurgery, as well as to Phyick. The judicious Phyician that hall be near at hand, will
eaily ditinguih them, and precribe Remedies proper for them. We do only pretend that whenoever the Caue hall lie in any intempery of the noble parts, no Remedy hall go beyond this.

div.head: Againt the Running of the Reins.
div.p: The Body being duly purged, and the malignity wept away, our Tincture is a Sovereign Remedy to top it, by comforting the parts, and to prevent any lachrymation or weaknes, which ue to follow that ditemper, and many times put the Patients to a great deal of impatiency, and the Phyician to his nonplus.

div.head: Againt Intemperies of the Liver, Spleen, and Kidneys.
div.p: This Tincture being given in a proper Vehicle, will rectifie them, as well by its Anatical temper, as by its Actinobolim and Specifick qualities.

div.head: Againt the Venereal Dieae, vulgarly called the Great Pox.
div.p:
This Dieae having its chief foundation in the Liver, which by the Malignant quality of this ditemper, hath lot his Tone, and dipered the Dieae thorough the whole Body. By the ue of this Tincture is brought to its right temper again; and all the malign • ty of
the Dieae expelled, by the Alexipharmacal and Specifick quality of it.

div.head: Againt Faintings.
div.p: Fainting is a udden failing of the trength, that is, a udden diminution of the Vital, and conequently of the Animal Actions. The Caue is a udden want of the Vital Spirits, which by the Virtue of this Tincture, and of our admirable Water mixed together, are on a udden repaired, and the Patient kept in the Land of the Living, as I have ufficiently proved upon divers perons that are alive to this day.

div.head: Againt Surfeitings.
div.p:
There are two kinds of Surfeits, one in quantity, the other in quality, but both many times mortal. The Surfeit in quantity is, when one eateth or drinketh more then his appetite deireth, and his trength can bear. The Surfeit in quality is, when one eateth or drinketh never o little of a thing that he hath a prejudice againt; both are immediately cured by the Tincture of Coral, mixed with our Cordial Water; not as the former Dieaes we have made mention of, either by Specifick qualities or Actinobolims, but by their gratefulnes and friendlines to our nature, which when it lieth under the burden of a Surfeit, and findeth the gratefulnes of this Remedy
it grapeth upon it, and lets fall the Matter of the Surfeit, which being looed it expelleth by Vomiting, without leaving any Particle of it behind, and o is immediately well, as I have tried many times, even to the admiration of the beholders.

div.head: Againt Vomitings.
div.p: This is a pernicious Symptom which is much in reign, when a Patient can retain nothing in his Stomach, but immediately bringeth it up all again, whether Meat, Drink, or Phyick. But this Tincture, and its Vehicle are o friendly to Nature, and of o admirable a Virtue, that it will immediately tay the Vomiting; And if there be any Caue of it, will bring it up, or if the Remedy tayeth with the Caue of the Vomiting in the Body, it will certainly conquer and detroy it.

Many more other Dieaes could I mention, in which the Tincture of Coral would effect wonderful things. But I think thee will be ufficient for any reaonable and ingenuous peron: Thoe that will know more, may advie with the Author, who hall ingenuouly tell them if it be fit for their ditemper or not, and in what Vehicle it mut be taken; adviing them eriouly, That if they receive no benefit by this Remedy in thoe Dieaes for
which it is properly adminitred, they can hardly expect it from any other. The Author having alo a peculiar Talent to judge of Dieaes, and the Remedies thereof, by the Inpection of Urines, deireth thoe that will ave charges or lives, afar of, to end their Water; by the examination of which, they hall receive all reaonable atisfaction: And for thee purpoes and others, he hall give his contant attendance at his own Houe, from eight of the clock in the Morning, till eleven; and from three in the Afternoon, till five. The ret of the time, it will be known where he is, and when he will be at home again.

Thoe alo that hall doubt of the reality and extraction of the aid Tincture, may have from him ome of his Mentruum, with which he extracteth it, and with that and their own Coral, make the experiment themelves.

div.head: CHAP. X.
How and in what Vehicles the Tincture of Coral is to be administred.
div.p:
THis Tincture being o noble and o precious, and working o powerfully in o little a quantity, is to be ued with all circumpection imaginable, that there be no wate in the quantity, nor impediment in the quality. There would be a great wate in the quantity, if it were taken alone, and by it elf, conidering, That one pound of Coral will carce yield above one drachm of Tincture; therefore we give it in a little quantity (uppoe of about twenty drops) in a proper Vehicle, uppoe of two or three ounces; that by its diffuion in it, it may go and enter over all the noble parts of the Body; as you ee that a grain of Cochenille will die a thouand times of its weight of Water; and that Saffron will diffue its Tincture in a prodigious quantity of liquor. There would alo be a wate in the quantity, if the Tincture were given alone, and by it elf; for the Natural heat would conume it, before it could diffue its virtue, and radiate thorough the
whole Body. Add alo, that a Specifick Vehicle will make it work more effectually and determinately upon the part aimed at. There would be alo an impediment in the quality, if it were not given in a Vehicle that were unfit, or contrary to the ditemper that it is given for; as if of two Hores, the one hould draw before, and the other back, they could hardly reach home in a convenient time; or, if it were given amongt Meat, or upon a full Stomach, it is evident, that its virtue hould be drowned, and its Radiation hindered: As when a thick cloud is interpoed between the Sun, and us. For the illutration of what we have aid, it is viible, and in a manner palpable, That if the aid Tincture were given againt the Plague and Malignant Feavers in Plantain Water, it would hardly work the deired effect, becaue Plantain Water is cool and atringent; and our intention in this, is to expel the malignity of the Plague and Feavers by a moderate weat, which cannot be conveniently procured, but by a hot Vehicle, uch as is our Cordial Water, or that of Carduus, and uch other-like. Contrariwie, if in immoderate Fluxes of Women and Haemorrhagies, it be adminitred in hot Vehicles, and not in cool and Atringent ones, uch as Plantain Water is, little good can be expected
of it, by reaon of the contrariety and diproportion that is between the Agent and the Patient, that is, the Remedy and the Dieae. Let it therefore be concluded, That it mut be given in a proper Vehicle, that is, uch a one, as is proper for the ditemper, and will forward the effect of the aid Tincture, and hath a peculiar analogy and correpondence with the Dieae aimed at. As for example, For the topping of all immoderate Fluxes in Men and Women, it ought to be given in Plantain Water, or the decoction of the Roots of Tormentil. For the cleaning or renewing of the Blood, in Fumitory or Cichory Water. For trengthning the Heart and the Vital Spirits, in Buglos, or Borrage Water. For comforting and trengthning the Stomach, in Mint or Penniroyal Water. For removing of obtructions in Sorrel Water, Little Centaury, Spleenwort, Liverwort. For diolving congealed Blood, in Water of Chervil or Daiie. For the Fits of the Mother, in the Water of Motherwort, Balm, Penniroyal. For the Dropie, Convulion, Palie, Falling-Sicknes, in Cinnamon Water, continuing for a while, becaue thoe Dieaes are tubborn. For the Stone and Gravel, in Saxifrage or Retharrow Water. The doe is from ix grains or ten, to a cruple or two, according to the
age and trength of the Patient, and the greatnes of the ditemper: And o it may be aid of all the ret of the ditempers which it is proper for. Upon which, the Author will give his advice to thoe that hall deire it; and for that purpoe, hall give his contant attendance at his own Houe, from eight of the clock in the Morning, till eleven; and from three in the Afternoon, till five. The ame Author having alo a pecial Talent to judge of Dieaes, and the Remedies thereof, by the Inpection of Urines, may be advied with at the aid time; therefore thoe that hall be minded to ave the charges of Fees, may at the aid time bring or end their Urine, upon ight whereof, they hall receive all reaonable atisfaction.

As for the aid Tincture of Coral, with the Vehicles proper for it, they are only to be had and minitred by him, to prevent all uppoition, falification, or mitakes, the World, at preent, being o full of Envy, Backbiting, and Deceitfulnes, that he dares trut no Body with it; but is reolved, as he is the ole Author of it, o to have all the praie of it, and bear all the blame alone, if any be. He alo carrieth always ome of the aid Tincture about him, ready to be adminitred, whenoever occaion hall require, that no time
may be lot, as mot commonly it is, in acute and exceeding haty Dieaes. That hall not hinder, but if any Body be atisfied with the Virtues and Effects of the aid Tincture, he may have of him what quantity he pleaeth to lie by him, againt the time of need; and this he doth to make good his Motto, which alo was that of Cardan. Io uon Medico non di parole ma d'effetto.
